captions.text:
Zero G, a phrase that people use all the time
to describe the phenomenon of perceived weightlessness.

Usually in space.
But zero G does not mean zero gravity because

there's gravity everywhere. If there were
truly no gravity in space, planets and stars

wouldn't even form, let alone orbit around
each other.

So gravity is a thing, everywhere all over.
But we sometimes refer to the effects of gravity

in a specific way as G-force. Despite its
name, not only is it not a measurement of

gravity, it's not a measurement of force either.
It's a unit of acceleration, and that acceleration
is usually caused by gravity.

Officially, one G is the acceleration of an
object caused by gravity near the surface

of the Earth. So you know, you throw your
phone out your window, you jump up into the

air or drop your keys on the street, they
fall at the same rate. About 9.8 meters per

second squared. That is known as standard
gravity.

Now 2G of course would just be double that.
You could experience that much acceleration

if you are speeding away from the Earth in
a spacecraft or in a drag racer that is blasted

from zero to 160 kilometers per hour. In those
situations, you experience G-force as a sensation
of weight.

As you hurtle along in your spaceship or your
dragster, you'd be pulled back into your seat,

and if there were a bathroom scale behind
you, it would register those G-forces.

But where you can't experience weight, you
can't experience G-force. And this is what

happens to astronauts in space. When they
orbit Earth, they are in a state of constant

free-fall. Basically they are continually
falling toward Earth but missing it and then
falling toward it some more.

So even though they are very much under the
influence of gravity, they aren't experiencing

G-force. So we call that environment zero
G, even though, confusingly enough, it is
not the same thing as zero gravity.

We should probably have come up with a better
name, but it is too late for that now.

Thanks for asking, and thanks to our Subbable
subscribers who keep these answers coming

and get the questions a little bit before
everybody else.

If you have a Quick Question, you can let
us know on Facebook or Twitter or Tumblr or

down in the comments below. And don't forget
to go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

title: Why Isn't "Zero G" the Same as "Zero Gravity"?

comments.text:
mann... this whole being "official" crap is lame.

g force only works for Earth anyway.

whats the point in having the term zero gravity if theres nowhere in the 
universe that it can apply to.
Might as well just repurpose the term to mean what it was intended to mean.

and by that I mean, observing force outside the influence of a particular 
body of mass gravity.

if theres gravity everywhere, might as well just state it based on a 
particular instead.

orbital freefall can just be, orbital cancelation [relative to whatever it 
is]

in another 200 years or whenever people are working outside this dumb rock, 
they're gonna look back at these stupid silly attempts we made to clarify 
the meaning of our terms and views and see just how out of place and 
practicality they are!

orbits are based on influence of mass bodies and trajectory acceleration, 
but cannot rule out the possibility of anomalies that can ignore, or fight 
against orbital masses, and choose to orbit in an asymmetric manner. this 
would undermine the principles of measuring g force and orbital freefall! 
another one would be the development of artificial gravity. this would 
completely mess up the current rules on mass bodies.

Trying to explain gravity and g-force when we cannot duplicate it or alter 
it just makes us look like we don't know what we're talking about. 
Especially when we give round about answers that dodge the 'pink elephant' 
in the room.

put it another way: what is the difference between being so far from the 
Earth, that the pull of influence from it, is within 10% similarity to the 
pull from the moon, and when you are in free falling orbit? Is there even a 
difference? why the need to contextually separate the two? Is it even a 
matter of gravity? or is it something else? Could you run this same 
experiment on the ground, or even under ground in a particular manner and 
get the same readings or results? What is g-force really if the one we 
measure isn't really a force, and is based solely on Earth's pull? What is 
Gravity really? What do we REALLY know?﻿

comments.author: Élyssa Ann

comments.text:
If you some how ended up in a cube that sat motionless (relative to the 
sun) within our solar system far away from any planet, would there be 
enough gravity from the sun to draw and hold you to the side of the cube 
facing the sun or would you freely float within the cube? And what would 
the G force be if it did draw you to the side?﻿
comments.author: scrappmutt2

comments.text:
To get 1g by hovering stationary above the sun, you'd need to be about 
three million kilometres from the sun's core (about 13 times closer to the 
sun than Mercury). Of course, if your ship can accelerate at 1g, you can do 
that anywhere and people will experience gravity in the direction opposite 
that of thrust. However, that will take a *lot* of fuel or reaction mass to 
maintain.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text:
That's ok, thanks!
I guess the reason i'm asking the question is when you see a scifi flick, 
usually people are walking upright within a space ship just as though they 
were on Earth (which I guess they really are), then you have the more high 
end movies that show them all floating weightless.
Being that we haven't yet found a way to mimic gravity other than through 
centrifugal force or  strapping a massive amount of material to the bottom 
of a ship, I was wondering if the gravity of the sun would give us that 
walk up right ability while in a ship that we see in the basic scifi movie, 
that and which type of movie may be more scientifically accurate.
comments.author: scrappmutt2

comments.text:
Oh, sorry, I misunderstood the question! If the cube is suspended, 
unmoving, then you'll feel the acceleration GM/r^2 towards the face closest 
to the sun.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text:
+Natasha Taylor But in this hypothetical, the cube is somehow suspended in 
space, not accelerating in any given direction relative to the sun. Would 
you then be pulled towards the sun or would you be floating in the middle?
comments.author: scrappmutt2

comments.text:
It's in freefall — every particle inside the meteor is being accelerated 
towards the sun at the same rate. Let's replace the meteor with the cube 
and put you inside it. You can't feel any acceleration because every 
particle in your body is accelerating at the same rate, and you don't get 
any closer to any of the sides of the cube because you're always falling at 
the same speed it is.

If we imagine that you were somehow immune to gravity, you would experience 
an acceleration pulling you to the side of the cube farthest from the sun, 
equal to GM/r^2 (with *M* being the mass of sun, *r* being your distance 
from it and *G* being the gravitational constant) — what's actually 
happening is the cube is accelerating and you're not.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text:
+Natasha Taylor Then that begs the question, how does a large asteroid 
shooting thousands of miles an hour get pulled back in the opposite way 
towards the sun? I always thought that was due to a strong gravitational 
pull from the sun that I would of thought would effect the body suspended 
in the cube.
comments.author: scrappmutt2

comments.text:
+scrappmutt2 You put the cube anywhere, even really close to a body, and 
you would freely float within the cube (so long as you're not close enough 
for tidal forces to be significant, like near a black hole or a neutron 
star). Even on Earth this applies — NASA does zero-g training with 
astronauts in an aeroplane in free-fall.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text: If light has no mass, why is it affected by gravity?﻿
comments.author: gothmog9407

comments.text:
+gothmog9407 You don't need mass to be affected by gravity, that's a 
Newtonian approximation. General relativity treats gravity as a curvature 
in space-time and its prediction that light should be 'bent' by gravity was 
actually one of the first tests to separate general relativity from 
Newton's gravity.

minute explanation. Also, I don't know why we had to learn orbital 
mechanics to understand the basic economics of space exploration. Like yes, 
I get that rocket science is super expensive, and a lot of the cost goes 
into changing orbits, yatta yatta, but man. That class was miserable, 
though I learned a surprising amount of weird, semi-related stuff.﻿
comments.author: Summer Leppanen

comments.text:
A more complete explanation based on the theory of relativity gets *really* 
weird when you think of the concept that something in freefall is actually 
not accelerating at all, and when you are standing on the earth, you are 
not pushing down on it -- it is pushing up on you because it is 
accelerating toward you at 9.81 m/s^2.

(The earth's surface on the side opposite you is also accelerating toward 
people on that side at 9.81 m/s^2 -- try to wrap your mind around the idea 
that two things that are not moving relative to each other can actually be 
accelerating away from each other! That is the nature of two things being 
at different points in a gravitational field.)

That is what is meant by the statement that gravity creates a warp in 
spacetime. Under the influence of gravity, a straight line through 
spacetime (when you follow it, you feel no G forces) happens to be a curved 
path through space, and vice versa.﻿

comments.text:
I am saying that it is poorly named, not that it is improperly used.

'Microgravity' seems to indicate there is less gravity or a weaker 
gravitational field.  But you can experience microgravity anywhere, 
regardless of how much gravity you are subjected to.  Even falling into a 
black hole you are in a 'microgravity environment', because you are in 
free-fall.

Weightlessness is a more appropriate name for microgravity.

Micro gravity is even worse.  If you are in the international space station 
you are subject to 88% of the gravitational acceleration experienced at the 
surface of Earth.  'Micro' makes it sound like it should be less than 1% (a 
micro meter is a millionth of a meter).  Zero G is misleading but at least 
it's technically correct

comments.author: Monkeyb00y

comments.text:
+Monkeyb00y It also depends where on the planet you are at sea level: at 
the poles its stronger than the equator, and depending on factors like 
nearby mineral deposits and groundwater, it can vary quite a bit locally. 
In fact, a 1% difference between locations isn't all that unusual, which 
makes the Olympics records unfair, because they don't account for either 
the local gravitational field or the difference in air pressure, which are 
important to the number of significant figures the records are drawn.

comments.author: Shawn Doyle

comments.text:
Would I actually be able to show the difference between zero G and no 
gravity, if I were in a closed box? Is there ANY measurement I could do to 
know the difference?﻿
comments.author: Henrik Kragh

comments.text:
+Henrik Kragh In some cases, yes. Let's say you're in a box, and you're 
trying to figure out whether you are a) in orbit around a body; b) in 
freefall towards a body; c) in freefall in a uniform gravitational field; 
or d) in a region of space with no gravity.

You can test the first hypothesis by spinning up a ball bearing really 
quickly: if it slowly turns, you can conclude by conservation of angular 
momentum that you're in orbit. If it doesn't, *b*, *c*, or *d* must be the 
case.

To test the second hypothesis, you can measure the tension between the 
floor and the ceiling: this will tell you if the gravity on the floor is 
stronger than the gravity on the ceiling. If so, then you can conclude 
you're in freefall towards a body, if not *c* or *d* are correct.

However, these last two can't be separated *unless* gravitational and 
inertial mass are different: if they are, then more massive objects will 
accelerate at a different rate to less massive objects, however as near we 
can tell this is not the case.

comments.text:
Hello, I have a question
When I listen to music or watch a video I listen with one earphone and 
sometimes I can hear the music or watch a video in the other ear, why?

please reply?﻿
comments.author: Grady Ramsay

comments.text:
I have a theory. (Totally unrelated to this video though). The softer the 
volume of a video, the more trustworthy the source﻿
comments.author: Alvis Ng

comments.text: His blatant over animation of his voice is so annoying.﻿
comments.author: Casey O'Brien

comments.text:
There is a special tone that certain people will use in their voice when 
they want to convey "I am supersmart, and I cannot possibly be mistaken in 
what I am telling you."  Just listen to Neil deGrasse Tyson or Carl Sagan 
as other classic examples.  I have much greater admiration for the tone 
used by people like Steven Weinberg, Sean Carroll and Richard Feynman.  
They are persuasive, while being much more skillful in avoiding the 
pitfalls of arrogance.  But tv and other mass-media will continue to favor 
the over-animation, as this is a big part of what sucks in the general 
public audience.  "They sound smart, therefore the must be right."
comments.author: Da Hawk

comments.text:
would gravity exist between galaxies in deep space? or would the existence 
of dark matter and that kind of thing still make gravity?﻿
comments.author: mamba701

comments.text:
+mamba701 Yes to both! In fact, because of gravity the Andromeda galaxy 
will collide with ours in roughly four billion years.

comments.text:
Question: Can we use Genetic Modifying to make Giant Pandas that can 
produce enough milk for two babies so Giant Panda mothers don't need to 
kill the weaker child when having twins?﻿
comments.author: Gustav Rammelsberg

comments.text:
I guess a giant panda  would have giant panda babies,and the problem would 
remain.
comments.author: Alice Eliot

comments.text:
+Gustav Rammelsberg No reason we couldn't, but it would raise questions of 
ethics, would be expensive and would require a great deal of research.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text: I tried to explain this to my teacher and she yelled at me a lot... ﻿
comments.author: Le Arrington

comments.text:
As it may be mentioned in the comments. While there is no such thing as 
zero gravity. What most people are implying when saying that is 
"micro-gravity" ﻿
comments.author: Blue

comments.text:
You are in 0G when your G meter reads 0.  The G meter (or accelerometer) is 
where the term 0G comes from.  If you are still having trouble wrapping 
your brain around why 0G does not mean 'no gravity' i would suggest you 
look into how a G meter works. ﻿
comments.author: NeoDemocedes

comments.text:
question: why do I sneeze in pairs? or do you already have a video on that 
subject? ﻿
comments.author: hannes van brabant

comments.text: Why Isn't "Zero G" the Same as "Zero Gravity"?: http://youtu.be/c8UpIJIVV4E﻿
comments.author: Juris Sudmalis

comments.text: Does turkey make you sleep?﻿
comments.author: David Nguyen

comments.text:
I understand the principles behind zero-G when in orbit, but what about in 
interplanetary/deep space (or even en route to the Moon)? Astronauts aren't 
still "falling" towards the surface of the Earth the way they are in orbit, 
but they still experience zero-G, correct?﻿
comments.author: Keegan Guidolin

comments.text:
Oh sorry, usually these sorts of examples refer to a lack of instruments 
that interact with the external universe to highlight a real symmetry or 
equivalence, rather than just pointing out that the human body sucks at 
detecting and discerning a wide variety of forces.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text: +Natasha Taylor ball-bearings and a stopwatch qualify as 'instruments'.
comments.author: NeoDemocedes

comments.text:
+NeoDemocedes You would be able to tell the difference. Spin a 
ball-bearing, and measure its rate of precession. Do this along three 
different axes and you'll have the speed at which your orbiting and the 
direction, thanks to conservation of angular momentum, completely without 
reference to the outside Universe.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor

comments.text:
In orbit or in deep space you will experience G-forces only when rocket 
engines are firing and you're (hopefully) strapped into your seat.  When 
the rocket engines are off, you, and the space craft are both adrift.  If 
you were sealed up in a spacecraft without any windows or instruments you 
wouldn't be able to tell the difference between low orbit, high orbit, or 
deep space.
comments.author: NeoDemocedes

comments.text:
+Keegan Guidolin You are considered in 'freefall' if there's nothing 
opposing your fall due to gravity, and in all cases you will experience 
zero-g, whether you're en-route to the moon or in the depths of 
intergalactic space.
comments.author: Natasha Taylor
